title: Ticket #6151: Make documented flag names human-readable.
description:
In particular, 'odi' and 'sfr' are odious. Flags that are specific to AWS should probably begin -aws (we can add a general version of the flag later, if it turns out be generalizable). 

        We probably have better things to do than to think about this too
hard, but I'm proposing the following based on our discussions.  Some of the
option names get rather long, but if we're worried about them not working
for Azure, we don't have a lot of choice (but see below for an idea about
that).  This help assumes GT# 6113 in the 'user data' section.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

usage: condor_annex -annex-name <annex-name> -count|-slots <number>

For on-demand instances:
        [-aws-on-demand]
        -count <integer number of instances>

For spot fleet instances:
        [-aws-spot-fleet]
        -slots <integer number of weighted capacity units>

To set the lease or idle durations:
        [-duration <lease duration in decimal hours>]
        [-idle <idle duration in decimal hours>]

To customize the annex's HTCondor configuration:
        [-config-dir </full/path/to/config.d>]

To set an instance's user data:
        [-aws-[default-]user-data[-file] <data|file> ]

To customize an AWS on-demand annex:
        [-aws-on-demand-instance-type <instance-type>]
        [-aws-on-demand-ami-id <AMI-ID>
        [-aws-on-demand-security-group-ids <group-ID[,groupID]*>
        [-aws-on-demand-key-name <key-name>]

To use a customize an AWS Spot Fleet annex, specify a JSON config file:
        [-spot-fleet-config-file <path/to/config.json>]

To reprint this help:
        [-help]

Expert mode (specify account and region):
        [-aws-access-key-file <path/to/access-key-file>]
        [-aws-secret-key-file <path/to/secret-key-file>]
        [-aws-ec2-url https://ec2.<region>.amazonaws.com]
        [-aws-events-url https://events.<region>.amazonaws.com]
        [-aws-lambda-url https://lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com]
        [-aws-s3-url https://s3.<region>.amazonaws.com]

Expert mode (specify implementation details):
        [-aws-spot-fleet-lease-function-arn <sfr-lease-function-arn>]
        [-aws-on-demand-lease-function-arn <odi-lease-function-arn>]
        [-aws-on-demand-instance-profile-arn <instance-profile-arn>]

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

        I discussed this briefly with TJ, and it seems like some of the
option names are getting rather long.  My proposal to address this, which we
agreed seemed both reasonable and implementable, had two parts:

(1) Break the -aws off the front of the options and make it its own
    flag, which is set by default.  That way you only have to type it
    (or -azure, if and when that happens) once.
(2) Break the -on-demand off the new front of the options and make it its
    own flag, which is set by default.  That way you only have to type it
    (or -spot-fleet) once.

This has the nice implementation side-effect of allowing the AWS-,
on-demand-, and spot- specific parsing/setup to happen in different
functions.

        To further encourage parsimony, we thought it would make sense for
the -on-demand and -spot-fleet flags to become options whose argument
specifies the size of the annex.  We could keep -count as a general flag of
you don't specify an annex type; TJ and like the idea, however, of having a
general flag for the count as well, because having a single positional
argument sometimes looks real funny.
